content.description:
Climb the roof on the back side of the large boulder furthest downhill on the west/far/climber's right side of the field.  Start with your right hand on the lowest two-pad sidepull in the crack in the middle of the roof and your left hand on a low white, half-pad edge.  Throw up left to a big ledge and continue working left to a big, blocky edge.  Work your way up the arete above it to top out.  Sustained throughout, including the topout mantle onto the arete.

The name commemorates how while scouting the route a protrusion on it snagged the trigger guard on my bear spray can and nailed me across my side and in my face.  The song and dance I made were not melodious.

"It's a scream!" --Lin Manuel Miranda



The boulder at the west/climber's right end of the field and closest to the water on that side.

Talus, but paddable.

See location beta below.  Climb the left side of the back face of this boulder.  You'll have another, smaller boulder right at your back.  Start sitting with your right hand on a crumbly two-pad edge and your left on a slopey, vertical edge.  Go straight up and top out slightly to the left.  You can do it!



Find the boulder roughly in the centre of the bottom part of the talus field.  This is the back side of it towards its left side.

Clean fall.

Climb the line of crimps on the left side of the back wall before it becomes a short talus jumble.  Start standing/squatting to the right of the detached, chest-high boulder and to the left of the crimps used to climb the tall crack splitting the face.  Start with your hands on a chest-height flat flake/crimp.  Move straight up to a generous right sidepull.  Move mostly straight up, but trend left.  Top out by reaching left to the top of the series of big, blocky rails that make up the left end of the wall starts to end and blend into the tall, straight top of the wall.

The worst of the loose flakes should be gone now, but the abrasion of the fresh crimpers isn't the only reason it's called the Exfoliator.



Climb the side of the back wall to the left of the obvious, tall crack that splits it.

Awkward landing with talus and a big block, but can be padded well enough.

Climb the left arete of the left (east) side of the big detached block in front of the back wall.

Please be nice and give me a few weeks to send it now that I've cleaned it :)



The left (east) side of the big detached block in front of the back wall.

Talus fall, but protectable.  An extra pad would help.

climbs.name: Friends Don't Let Friends Skip Slab Day

content.description:
Climb the tall slab at the back of a corridor formed by two large boulders.  Easy and featured, but a lot of fun.



On the east/climber's left side (the one you first encounter when you get to the area).  It's behind the first large, detached boulder you encounter - it's at the end of a little corridor this boulder forms with the one next to it.

Clean but long fall.

One of the best routes in the area in terms of moves, aesthetics, and rock quality. Climb the obvious, slightly winding splitter on the left side of the back wall of the area.  It's a finger corner crack, but there are flakes to the left that ease it.  The fall becomes difficult to pad and spot right as you pull into the crux about 2/3 up and mildly terrifying as you pull through the full-value, sloping mantle topout.



The obvious splitter crack on the left side of the large face at the back-right (west) side of the area.

Tall.  Also tough to pad and spot so you don't hit the boulder behind the route on your way down.

Climb the featured fist crack toward the right (west) side of the back wall.



Toward the right end of the back wall.

Blocky fall.

Climb the slabby back side of the detached block in front of the right side of the back wall.  Climb it where the boulder is tallest, but avoiding the smaller detached blocks leaning against the right side of the boulder's back side.



The back side of the big detached block in front of the right (west) side of the back wall.

Clean ground, but a spotter would need to keep you from hitting the wall behind you.

Start sitting (as much as it's possible to do so in the fissure) on a crimp rail.  Move up and left to a thin crimp, right to a big sidepull, and slap the moss carpet on top to finish.  When you're down in the fissures in the area, you can always feel a cold wind coming out of the ground from the parts that never thaw.



On the back face of the fissure behind the back wall.  Toward the right end of it.

Short, clean fall.

Climb the short slab uphill and right from Friends Don't Let Friends Skip Slab Day.



To climber's right of Friends Don't Let Friends Skip Slab Day.  It's slightly uphill from it on the other/right side of the boulder that creates part of the corridor for that route.

Clean enough fall.

The crack splitting the back wall that forms Northern Comfort goes all the way through it and forms a fist crack in a 2-3'-wide fissure behind the back wall in the ground.  Let yourself down into the fissure and climb back out with the fist crack.  Dirty but fun.



Directly back from Northern Comfort in the fissure behind the back wall.

Clean fall.

Climb the obvious, overhanging, flakey groove on the front side of the big, detached block in front of the back wall.  Start sitting with your hands on the flat top of the first big flake and go straight up.  The mantle over the edge is slopier than you'd expect.  Also unavoidably dirty and vegetated.  Power through it all from start to finish - fairly consistent difficulty, despite the switch in styles halfway through.  Get on it now because the big flake all the key holds are on flexes a good centimetre when you're on it.

There could be a low start to the right, though it verges on contrived.



Right in the middle of the "front" (river-facing) face of the big, detached block in front of the back wall.

Clean fall.

This will likely be the first route you encounter in the Disproving Ground.  It's the slightly overhanging offwidth crack splitting the middle of the face of the first tall, detached block you'll encounter after thrashing out of the brush.  Start sitting on the convenient, flat talus pile in front of it with your hands in the small adjacent crack around a detached-looking block in the side of the crack that amazingly holds.  Work up through odd and awkward but interesting moves through the surprisingly featured crack until you can gun for the big shelf on the left to set you up for the topout mantle.  Welcome to the bungle.



The first large, detached boulder you encounter when you get to the area.  It's on the side that faces the rest of the boulder field.

Clean enough fall.

The last area in the Hidden Valley before it joins the Cameron River. These boulders are just uphill from the river itself as the series of rock walls that form the southern edge of the Hidden Valley from Trail's End to here disappear into the river.

The Hidden Valley saves the best for last. This area has far and away the best concentration of taller and high quality routes I've found so far in the area. It contains a variety of climbing styles and difficulties, from easy to harder, and most of the routes make for solid personal test pieces in the area.  If you can climb a route of any grade here, you've got the skill and mental nerve to climb them anywhere else in the area.  Interesting, quality moves on aesthetic lines in one of the most aesthetic parts of the Valley.  A great place to prove or disprove yourself after you've worked your way to the end of the Valley.
